awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Collaborative Research: A Computational Framework for Reconstructing and Visualizing Myocardial Active Stresses
awd_abstract_narration:
The normal heart functions by contracting and pushing the blood from the left ventricle into the rest of the body. Due to various diseases, the contraction capabilities of the heart become diminished in certain regions of the heart chamber wall, compromising the overall function of the heart. In order to identify and select optimal treatment, it is critical to identify the regions of the heart wall that exhibit reduced contractions. Unfortunately, contractions cannot be easily measured. This project will estimate the stress (contraction power) developed within the heart muscle by combining medical imaging and mechanical modeling of the heart. These stresses will serve as a quantitative measure of the contractile function of the heart and help detect and localize disease. Therefore, this research has the potential to evolve into a future tool to diagnose cardiac function. This project will also feature a synergistically integrated education and outreach program. We will foster research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in computer science, biomedical engineering, mathematics, and imaging science at Rochester Institute of Technology and the University of Kansas. The PIs will develop innovative hands-on workshops to inspire and educate K-12 students from underrepresented groups on biomedical computing and medicine.
 
This project proposes to develop a method that enables non-invasive appraisal and visualization of the active stresses developed in the myocardium to serve as a direct means to assess the bio-mechanical function of the heart. The PIs will develop open-source cyberinfrastructure and integrate it into a novel computational framework for cardiac biomechanics that will reconstruct the active stresses from cardiac deformations. The PIs will accomplish this goal by developing and integrating techniques for medical image computing, high-order meshing, and inverse-problem bio-mechanical modeling. This research will address a currently unexplored niche in the cardiac modeling field, specifically the reconstruction and visualization of myocardial active stresses, to enable direct appraisal of cardiac function. This research will contribute to medical image computing through the development of algorithms for medical image processing and visualization. The PIs will develop and implement novel high-order meshing techniques and integrate them with the fiber architecture to enable accurate and efficient scientific modeling and computing. The project will contribute new knowledge in mathematical modeling and simulation by implementing efficient nonlinear least-squares solutions for inverse cardiac biomechanics. Lastly, the PIs will release the resulting cyberinfrastructure to the scientific computing community for research and education use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the project is to research and create a method that enables non-invasive appraisal and visualization of the active stresses developed in the myocardium to serve as a direct means to assess the bio-mechanical function of the heart. This collaborative project was aimed at developing computational tools that could be integrated into a novel computational framework for cardiac biomechanics that will help reconstruct, quantify, and visualize the active stresses from cardiac deformations. The PIs have accomplished these goals by developing and integrating techniques for medical image computing, high-order meshing, and inverse-problem bio-mechanical modeling methods. This research has the potential to help address a currently unexplored niche in the cardiac modeling field, specifically the reconstruction and visualization of myocardial active stresses, to enable direct appraisal of cardiac function. 

The role of the RIT team, led by Dr. Linte, in collaboration with Dr. Otani, has been to develop the necessary tools for medical image computing biomechanical modeling techniques for use in cardiac simulations. The role of the collaborating team at KU, lead by Dr. Shontz, has been to develop high-order meshing algorithms and use them to generate 3D dynamic cardiac models which include the fiber architecture.

Dr. Linte and his mentees worked on developing and utilizing medical image computing tools to extract the cardiac geometry from clinical cardiac MRI images, reconstruct cardiac geometry and cardiac motion throughout the cardiac cycle, and estimate cardiac deformations from the 4D (3D + time) imaging data. Dr. Shontz and her team used these data to generate dynamic high-order finite element meshes of the cardiac geometry and fiber architecture.

Dr. Otani and his personnel have developed and implemented mathematically robust and computationally efficient model of cardiac biomechanics in the form of both a forward and inverse problem. The model was implemented and demonstrated on simplified cardiac geometries using synthetically generated cardiac motion that mimicked the motion extracted from the 4D (3D + time) cardiac MRI images, and optimized in collaboration with Dr. Shontz.

In the context of intellectual merit, this project yielded new knowledge and new computational tools for cardiac image segmentation, registration, and motion extraction; static and dynamic patient-specific models of the cardiac geometry; deformable, hybrid mesh models of the heart chambers (left and right ventricles) that portray the cardiac dynamics throughout the cardiac cycle; and forward and inverse models that couple cardiac motion, biomechanical tissue properties, and active stresses.

In the context of broader impact, the developed image computing tools can be applied to extract features of interest from any medical images, as well as other images not necessarily medical in nature, with several adaptations, as necessary. Many of the developed techniques rely on using different convolutional neural network architectures, which can therefore be trained on existing or new datasets dedicated to various applications. Specifically, we have demonstrated the use of the developed deep learning –based segmentation tools to extract surgical instruments from laparoscopic / endoscopic video sequences, as well as to reconstruct depth and surface topology, generate depth maps from stereo video images, learn feature descriptors from pre-procedural and intra-operative mages, and use them to co-register images and models for enhanced visualization during image-guided intervention and navigation. Moreover, the modeling work, both the forward and inverse problem simulations and implementations, can be applied to model other organ systems, as well as to other models in different disciplines that rely on simulations and inverse problem solutions in stress analysis, (bio)mechanics, or heat transfer including fields such as fluid mechanics, aerospace engineering, or mechanical engineering.

In the context of education and outreach, the team hosted a summer camp at the University of Kansas, as well as participated n several workshops at Rochester Institute of Technology in both the School of Mathematical Sciences and the College of Engineering where high school students from various communities, including underrepresented minorities, were exposed to the concepts of computational imaging and modeling applied to biomedical prblems. In addition, the team also co-organized several special sessions at various conferences in the field; lastly, some of the team members were also engaged in several other workshops dedicated to career and professional development and lifelong learning.

The project provided full support for three PhD students in Imaging Science and Mathematical Modeling at RIT, as well as partial support for three undergraduate students and three other graduate students. The research was disseminated in more than 45 peer-reviewed journal articles and peer-reviewed conference proceedings, all of which were authored by students, who served as lead authors and also delivered all presentations at various accepted conferences in the field.

Lastly, this project helped three investigators from two different institutions with expertise spanning three different disciplines establish a long-term collaboration at the intersection of medical imaging, scientific computing, and mathematical modeling, with a direct application to the biomedical arena.
